newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russia's Volga-Dnepr plans to increase its fleet.
newsitem.headline: Russia's Volga-Dnepr plans to increase its fleet.

text.p: Russian private cargo airline Volga-Dnepr will buy an Antonov-124-100 heavy freighter before the end of this year, increasing its fleet of such planes to seven aircraft, a company spokesman said on Tuesday.
"We are in final talks with Russian plane-maker Aviastar to buy this plane," Konstantin Rogov told Reuters.
The plane will be operated on international charters.
Rogov did not reveal the aircraft's cost.
He also said Volga-Dnepr planned to lease two Tupolev-204 cargo jets. "We need such planes, but only if they are powered by Western-made engines," he added.
"An-124s, which have a capacity of 120 tonnes, carried 14,467 tonnes of cargo between January and June," Rogov said, adding this was a 55 percent increase over the corresponding period of 1995.
He said the aircraft frequently carried aerospace and oil exploration equipment.

Ulyanovsk-based Volga-Dnepr operates 14 cargo planes -- six An-124s, five Il-76s, two An-12s and one An-32. It had sales of $87.2 million in 1995 compared with $87.8 million in the previous full year.
